text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with marble potatoes that's right
these little baby new potatoes used to
only be available to the fancy chefs but
lately I've been seeing these at the
market and by the way if you have both a
fishnet stocking and potato fetish this
video is for you so we're gonna roast
these potatoes but because they're so
small we're not going to use the oven
we're gonna roast them in a pan with
bacon I know that does sound good so
let's get started so I have a 1 pound
bag of what's called tri-colored marble
potatoes
we got the red we got the gold and we
got what I believe is Peruvian purple so
I'm gonna dump those in a bowl we're
going to give those a really good rinse
alright give a scrub if you have to but
they're generally pretty clean and then
as promised we're going to roast these
in a pan with bacon so I'm going to
throw a handful of sliced bacon into a
dry saute pan on medium heat and I'm
just going to give it a few minutes head
start we just wanted to start rendering
out a little bit of that fat so just let
it go for a couple minutes and when you
see it start to sizzle go ahead and dump
in your drained marble potatoes oh and
by the way for you young viewers marbles
were little glass balls that our
grandparents played with because they
didn't have video games it was a tough
life and along with that we're gonna add
a big pinch of salt and a little bit of
freshly ground black pepper and we're
gonna give that a stir and then here's
what's going to happen we're gonna
continue cooking this on medium heat the
bacon is going to eventually slowly
crisp up and as it does it's going to
release fat and those little potatoes
are going to roast just with the heat
coming from the surface of the pan so
we're really taking advantage of the
size here to use a different method so
I'm going to cook that stirring
occasionally for about five or six
minutes until my bacon sort of starts to
look like it's getting cooked it's going
to look something like that at that
point I'm just going to throw on the lid
and I'm gonna let that cook for about
five minutes I'm going to remove the lid
I'm going to give it a stir and I'm
going to repeat that process until the
potatoes are tender and even though all
the fat's going to render out of the
bacon it's going to start getting crispy
because we're going to keep putting the
lid back on moisture is going to be
retained and condensation will drip into
the pan and you won't have to worry
about the bacon burning or the potatoes
burning it should be fine
so keep taking the lid off checking it
giving it a stir and you'll actually
feel with your spatula or spoon the
potatoes will start to soften up so a
very simple procedure you're just going
to roast those potatoes in
that bacon fat until they're tender and
how will you know you're gonna test with
the tip of a knife so I gave mine the
old poka poka and it was tender and
instead of throwing it back in I ate it
to give it a taste and I decided to need
a little more salt and a little pepper
and then this is pretty much ready to
eat and would be incredibly delicious
but wait there's more we're going to add
a nice dusting of freshly chopped
rosemary never not awesome with bacon
and potatoes and then we're going to
turn the heat off and we're going to
drizzle in a little bit of rice vinegar
into that hot pan again the Heat's off
and most of that's going to evaporate
right away as you're stirring it but
that's okay it's going to deglaze the
pan a little bit and it's going to make
everything go a little sticky and
slightly more awesome so just give that
a quick stir and then transfer to your
serving platter now I'm showing this as
a hot potato side dish but if you wanted
to go full potato salad with this just
dump in a big splash of your favorite
salad dressing give it a toss with those
warm potatoes and once it cools down you
would have one of the best potato salads
ever and above and beyond a great hot
and/or cold side dish these would also
be perfect for that pretend we're Giants
dinner party so there's another idea and
then we'll finish off with a little
rosemary sprig you know in case any food
bloggers show up and start to finish
that whole pan roasting thing only took
about 20-25 minutes
so it didn't take that long and I
thought the results were very very
delicious and beautiful and it's funny
you don't really think a potatoes is
being flavorful but because these are so
small they really do have more of a root
vegetable flavor than a big potato and
of course these will be easier for you
to eat because you're not looking at a
viewfinder but eventually I stabbed it
and it was delicious so I'm not sure if
it's just a springtime thing or if these
are going to be available other times of
the year but if you can find some or
some other kind of little new potatoes I
hope you give this easy technique a try
so head over to food wishes comm for all
the ingredient amounts and more info as
usual and as always enjoy
you
